Graphical abstract In this study, 15 wt. % NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts modified by La2O3 promoter were prepared through a co-precipitation route and employed for syngas production via propane steam reforming. Various techniques including X-Ray diffraction, BET, TPR, CO2-TPD, CO-chemisorption, TPO, and Scanning electron microscopy were utilized to characterize the final samples. The results indicated that the incorporation of La2O3 enhanced the metal-support interaction providing less reducible Ni species. In comparison with the La-free catalyst, the promoted ones possessed higher metal dispersion and smaller Ni particles. Nonetheless, excessive amounts of La covering the active sites negatively decreased the Ni dispersion and corresponding surface area. In addition, upon the introduction of La2O3 the strength and amount of strong basic sites enhanced owing to the preferential adsorption of CO2 on La2O3. The evaluation of the catalytic performance disclosed that despite the improved metal dispersion, the promoted catalysts possessed lower propane conversion and hydrogen yield than the un-promoted one. It might be attributed to the decrease in the acidic sites which contributed to CHx decomposition. Nevertheless, the highest activity was achieved with 3 wt. % La2O3 loading which was induced by highly dispersed metallic Ni and more accessible active sites for adsorption and dissociation. It was also confirmed that, the existence of La2O3 improved the resistance against coke formation owning to the formation of well-dispersed Ni species and acceleration of gasification reaction through the La2O2CO3. Keywords Propane Steam reforming magnesium silicate La promoter coke formation Introduction Synthesis gas as a mixture of H2 and CO, continues to attract great interest due to the widespread utilization in various industrial processes for the production of methanol, ammonia, liquid hydrocarbons, etc. Moreover, the utilization of fossil fuels as a non-renewable energy source causes serious problems including air pollution and natural resource depletion. Hydrogen as an efficient environmentally friendly energy carrier appears as a viable alternative energy source to existing fossil fuels. In this venue, the current researches are mainly focused upon the major routes for hydrogen and/or syngas production. Amongst various technologies for syngas production, steam reforming of hydrocarbons is the most economic and efficient method due to the highest yield of hydrogen, which is widely used around the world. Light hydrocarbons such as propane take into consideration as a proper feedstock for steam reforming owing to the high hydrogen yield at a temperature lower than that needed for other fuels such as methane [1]. Unique properties of propane including; its high energy density, easy transportation, and storage attributed to its liquefying capability at ambient temperature and moderate pressure along with well-developed distribution infrastructure lead to a prominent feed candidate especially for mobile applications[2]. The main propane steam reforming reactions could be presented as follows: i) highly endothermic propane steam reforming, ii) water-gas shift, and iii) Boudouard reactions [3] i.e.; (1) C 3 H 8 + 3 H 2 O ↔ 3 C O + 7 H 2 Δ H 298 ° = 499 k J / m o l (2) C O + H 2 O ↔ C O 2 + H 2 Δ H 298 ° = - 41 k J / m o l (3) 2 C O ↔ C + C O 2 Δ H 298 ° = - 172 k J / m o l From the thermodynamic view point, it is an endothermic reaction, which provides complete conversion for propane at a temperature higher than 500 °C. Steam reforming reaction is usually accompanied by various by-products and undesired side reactions including hydrocarbon cracking and Boudouard reaction, which contribute to the catalyst deactivation via coke formation. Moreover, it is known that high reaction temperature and the presence of water significantly accelerate the active site sintering, as a major catalyst deactivation mechanism[4]. Hence, the development of a suitable catalyst with remarkable resistance against coke deposition and thermal sintering becomes a serious challenge especially for large scale applications [5]. Noble metals based catalysts including Pd, Pt, Rh, and Ru possessed excellent performance along with considerable resistance against coke deposition [6,7]. Nevertheless, owing to the limited accessibility and relatively high cost, their commercial and industrial utilization are restricted. Alternatively, transition metals particularly nickel are conventionally used for steam reforming reactions because of their reasonable activity, affordable price, and abundant suppliers. In this venue, considerable effort has been invested in further enhancement of Ni-based catalysts’ deactivation resistance. Employing novel preparation methods, fabrication of bi-/tri metallic structure, and modification by alkaline and alkaline earth metal oxides are frequently reported in the open literature as common approaches [8–10]. Besides, rare earth elements modifiers such as La2O3 has been founded to provide great thermal stability and coke removing from the catalyst surface [11,12]. Studies conducted by Martinez et al. [13] revealed the better active site dispersion, higher conversion as well as a remarkable decrease in the carbon formation in methane dry reforming over lanthanum modified Ni/Al2O3 catalyst compared to the non-promoted one. According to Tsipouriari et al.[14] the addition of La2O3 can introduce moderate basic sites enhancing the CO2 adsorption on the catalyst surface to form lanthanum oxycahrbonate species (La2O2CO3). These species which are developed on the top of nickel particle or at the Ni-La interface, have been proposed to accelerate the conversion of CHx species and eliminate the deposited carbon via the following reaction Eq.(4): La2O2CO3+C→ La2O3+2CO [15]. Furthermore, research findings also revealed that La2O3 can exert a great influence on the prevention of active sites sintering. Based on the literature, strong interaction between La2O3 and NiO promoted the active site dispersion, thereby lessening the size of Ni particle and the chance of sintering. Mo et al. [16] developed the highly dispersed Ni-La2O3/SiO2 catalyst with a remarkable resistance against coke deposition for methane dry reforming. They reported that La2O3 promoted catalysts exposed excellent catalytic activity and stability with a negligible amount of coke formation resulting from enhancing the metal-support interaction and active phase dispersion. The similar observations are also reported by other researches [17–20]. In previous studies performed by these authors, a deep focus upon development of a novel mixed oxides supported nickel catalyst for propane steam reforming conducted. It is well accepted that, the catalyst support can play a leading role in the catalytic performance. In other words, active phase dispersion, metal-support interaction, and acid-base characteristics are the major parameters directly influenced by the support nature[21–25]. It is known that SiO2 supported Ni catalysts with a great performance in methane decomposition [26] have been proven to expose a high surface area, although its low dispersion capacity and weak metal-support interaction cause rapid coke formation and particles agglomeration [27]. On the other hand, it has been suggested that the utilization of basic supports such as MgO can significantly lower the carbon deposition as a result of more CO2 chemisorption which can accelerate the reverse Boudouard reaction[28,29]. Moreover, MgO can be incorporated in solid solution formation with NiO providing strong metal-support interaction and long-time stable activity[30–33]m. Hence, the combination of SiO2 and MgO was selected as promising support and the effect of synthesis parameters along with nickel loading and mixed oxides ratio on the physicochemical characteristics and catalytic performance during propane steam reforming was discussed comprehensively in our former research [34]. Considering the above literature knowledge, the catalytic activity of NiO-MgO-SiO2 particularly carbon resistance could be further enhanced via introducing a small amount of rare earth metals that promote the metal dispersion and reduce particle size. The current work was undertaken to study the promotional effect of La2O3 on Ni-based catalysts for propane steam reforming. The NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts were prepared through a co-precipitation route following by a hydrothermal treatment. The evaluation of their catalytic performance was performed concerning propane conversion, hydrogen yield, and short-time stability. Besides, the physicochemical characteristics of the promoted catalysts were taken into account by X-ray diffraction, BET, TPR, CO2-TPD, CO chemisorption, and SEM techniques. Experimental Catalyst preparation NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts with various La2O3 contents were prepared through the co-precipitation route, which further followed by a hydrothermal treatment. The un-promoted catalyst contained 15 wt.% of NiO and the balance (of 85 wt.%) as the MgO-SiO2 acting as a support. The molar ratio of MgO to SiO2 was 0.5. All the promoted catalysts also contained 15 wt.% of NiO, (85-x) wt.% of the MgO-SiO2 (support) with a molar ratio of MgO to SiO2 equal to 0.5. the “x” is being the wt.% of La2O3 possessing numerical values of 1.5, 3, 4.5, and 6. Magnesium nitrate hexahydrate (Mg (NO3)2.6H2O), Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni (NO3)2.6H2O), sodium silicate nonahydrate (Na2SiO3.9H2O) and Lanthanum nitrate hexahydrate (La (NO3)3.6H2O) were used as metal salt precursors. An aqueous solution of NaOH and Polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) was used as precipitant and surfactant, respectively. Initially, an appropriate amount of Mg (NO3)2.6H2O, Ni (NO3)2.6H2O, La (NO3)3.6H2O, Na2SiO3.9H2O and PVP were dissolved in distilled water, individually. Afterward, an aqueous solution of Ni, Mg and La nitrates was added into the PVP solution by the rate of 3cc/min under continued vigorous stirring. After the nitrate materials were fed completely into the solution, addition of the sodium silicate aqueous solution was initiated by the rate of 3cc/min. Since the sodium silicate solution is alkaline, this step was accompanied by a marked increase in the pH value. When this value was reached to 9, a 0.5 M HNO3 solution was injected dropwise into the above mixture. This latter addition was done to adjust the pH to the value of 9. The resulting pale green slurry was was heated at 200 °C in a stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon liner for 7 h. Afterward, the final mixture was filtered, washed several times with distilled water, dried at 90 °C overnight, and finally calcined at 500 °C for 3 h under air atmosphere. Catalyst characterizations The crystalline phase and structure of the calcined powder were characterized by using an X-ray powder diffractometer (Philips X’pert-Pro), using a Cu-Kα radiation source and a nickel filter in the 2θ range of 10-90°. The standard Scherrer formula (Eq.5) was employed to calculate the average crystalline size of the samples. (5) D = 0.9 λ β C o s θ In this equation, θ is the diffraction peak position, D represents the crystalline size (nm), β is the full-width at half-maximum intensity (FWHM) and λ is the X-ray radiation wavelength (0.15405 nm). The specific surface area and pore size distribution were studied through nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K applying an automatic gas adsorption analyzer (Tristar 3020, Micrometrics). Multi-point Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) methods were used to determine the surface area and pore size distribution, respectively. Before the measurement, the samples were purged under vacuum at 200 °C for 3 h. A micromeritics chemisorb 2750 instrument was used to perform the temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) analysis of the prepared samples. 100 mg of the calcined catalyst was loaded in a U-shape quartz reactor under a 20 ml/min flow of a reducing gas stream (5% H2 in Ar) and heated from ambient temperature to 1000° with a ramp rate of 10 °Cmin-1. The H2 uptake was measured as a function of temperature. Before the reduction, the sample was purged under N2 stream at 200 °C for 1 h. CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) was performed using a similar apparatus as described for H2-TPR analysis. 100 mg of the calcined powder was preheated at 40 °C for 1 h under the CO2 stream. After cooling down to room temperature, the sample was purged by a He stream with a ramp rate of 10 °C/min up to 1000 °C. Before the experiment, the sample was degassed under the N2 stream at 200 °C for 1 h. CO chemisorption of the reduced catalysts was conducted to calculate the Ni dispersion, particle size, and active metal surface area. This analysis was performed using the same apparatus as described for H2-TPR analysis. 100 mg of the reduced catalyst was subjected to He stream and pulses of CO which are injected through the catalyst at 4 °C. The transient response was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector until no further CO uptake was detected. A similar instrument as described for TPR analysis was applied for the evaluation of the type and amount of deposited carbon. In this measurement, an oxidizing gas flow (5% O2 in He, 20 ml/min) was purged over the degassed sample and the temperature increased from ambient temperature to to 1000 °C by the rate of 10 °C/min. The morphological characteristics of the spent catalysts were studied by scanning electron microscopy analysis (SEM) applying a MIRA2 TESCAN instrument. Catalytic performance The evaluation of the catalytic activity of the prepared samples was performed in a tubular fixed-bed quartz reactor (7 mm i.d) under atmospheric pressure at various temperatures. 0.1 g catalyst (250-500 μm) was placed into the reactor, which was located vertically inside an electrical furnace. Before the reforming test, all the catalyst samples were reduced in situ under 25 ml/min pure hydrogen stream at 550 °C for 3 h. Steam reforming was performed by introducing the feed stream containing C3H8 and He (molar ratio 25:75) along with steam. The analysis of the effluent gas composition was performed using a gas chromatograph (Younglin 6000). The following equations were employed to determine the conversion, yield, and selectivity. (6) % C 3 H 8 c o n v e r s i o n = m o l e s o f C 3 H 8 c o n v e r t e d t o t a l m o l e s o f C 3 H 8 i n t h e f e e d * 100 (7) % C 3 H 8 c o n v e r s i o n = m o l e s o f C 3 H 8 c o n v e r t e d t o t a l m o l e s o f C 3 H 8 i n t h e f e e d * 100 (8) % C - c o n t a i n i n g p r o d u c t s e l e c t i v i t y f o r A = m o l e s o f C i n p r o d u c t A m o l e s o f C i n a l l C - c o n t a i n i n g p r o d u c t s * 100 Results and discussion Catalyst characterizations The X-Ray diffractometer (XRD) patterns of the 15 wt. % NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts with various La contents are displayed in Fig. 1 . The observed diffraction peaks at 2θ = 19.6°, 27.9°, 35.9°, 53.6°, 60.8°, and 72.03° can be assigned to nanocrystalline phase of MgSiO3 (JCPDS No.002-0048). It is worth nothing that no individual diffraction peaks referred to NiO, La2O3, or Ni-La containing phases were observed. It might be due to their low percentage, high dispersion, and/or low crystallinity which is in accordance with that reported in the open literature [35,36]. It could be induced by the preparation method and support material providing a mesoporous structure with large specific surface area leading to well-dispersed metal species with no observable peaks in XRD pattern. According to Zhang et al. [37] research, two main reasons are responsible for great dispersion of metal oxides. These included: (i) monolayer dispersion effect and (ii) the interaction of NiO with La2O3 to from La-Ni mixed oxide causing the formation of very small and non-detectable particles. More precisely, the addition of La slightly lowered the intensity of the diffraction peaks. It indicates that the presence of La restricts the crystal growth and favors the amorphous structure. Hence, the promoted samples exhibited lower crystallinity and smaller crystalline size than the non-promoted catalyst. The crystalline sizes calculated via standard Scherrer formula were reported in Table 1 . As can clearly be seen, the introduction of La decreased crystalline size from 10.6 nm to 9.5 nm. The Nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherms and pore size distribution of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 2 a and b, respectively. Taking into account the IUPAC classification, all the prepared samples exhibited a type IV isotherm indicating the mesoporous structure [38]. The observed hysteresis at the medium relative pressure confirmed the occurrence of pore condensation. The hysteresis loops are categorized as a type H2, which is given by solids containing particles crossed by nearly cylindrical channels or made by aggregates/agglomerates of spherical particles with non-uniform pore shape/size [39]. The sharp N2 uptake at P/P0<0.05 assigns to the filling of small micro pores [40]. Besides, the incorporation of La shifted the starting point of the hysteresis loop to higher relative pressure indicating the existence of larger pores in the promoted samples. By contrast, the area of the hysteresis loops remained nearly constant due to the similar pore volumes and number of mesopores[41]. Regarding the pore size distribution, all samples possessed a unimodal narrow pore size distribution between 2 and 18 nm with a maximum located at around 4 nm. Addition of La resulted in slight movement of the pore size distribution to the larger one indicating the presence of larger meso pores. More precisely, the addition of 6 wt.% promoter led to the formation of larger mesopores causing a slight peak shift as well as shape change in Fig. 2(a) in comparison to the other samples. Moreover, the corresponding shape change of this figure also indicated a relatively broader pore size distribution was being involved here. The textural characteristics of the synthesized catalysts with various La loadings are reported in Table 1. The results show that the promoted catalysts possessed the lower specific surface area as well as pore volume than the un-promoted one. NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalyst without La exhibited the largest surface area and pore volume of 691 m2 g-1 and 0.78 cm3 g-1, respectively. The incorporation of 1.5 wt. % lanthanum appeared to lower the specific surface area from 691m2/g to 637 m2/g. Although quite similar BET area and pore volume were observed in the samples containing 3 and 4.5 wt. % of La2O3, further loading up to 6 wt.%, led to more decrease in BET surface area and pore volume to 574 m2 g-1 and 0.73 cm3 g-1, respectively. The inevitable decline in the BET surface area and pore volume signifies the successful diffusion of the promoter to the support mesopores. This also can be suggested that the partial blockage of small pores and coverage catalyst surface by lanthanide clusters could induce a decrease in these textural attributes in particular for 6 wt. % La2O3 loading [42–44]. Temperature programmed reduction analysis (TPR) The H2-TPR analysis was performed to evaluate the metal-support interaction and elucidate the role of La promoter in the reduction behavior of the fresh catalysts. the TPR results for the prepared catalysts with various La loadings are displayed in Fig. 3 . As can be observed, the reduction of NiO initiated at about 600 °C, which was followed by two main reduction peaks. The first reduction band, appearing as a shoulder in the range of 650-820 °C, is associated with the reduction of nickel oxides strongly interacted with non-reducible oxides [45]. The second reduction peak at high temperature region is attributed to the reduction of NiO species incorporated deeply into the carrier lattices to form NiO-MgO solid solution during calcination[46]. The solid solution formation rendered surface segregation leading to less reducibility [47]. According to the open literature, the reduction of “free state” nickel oxide weakly interacted with support takes place at below 500 °C depending on the condition. Herein, no reduction peak was indicated at a temperature lower than 550°, revealing the absence of any bulk nickel in the prepared catalysts. This result has been already confirmed by XRD results. From Fig. 3 it is clear that the addition of La shifted the maximum reduction temperature (Tmax) toward higher temperature of about 880 °C. it means that the presence of La enhanced the metal-support interaction due to the limitation of particle agglomeration, providing less (hardly-poorly) reducible NiO species [48]. More precisely, the last reduction peak of promoted catalysts is more intense than that observed in unpromoted one. It can be suggested that the promoted samples contain more NiO species involving in solid solution structure and high-level interaction with support. It is worthy to note that increasing the La loading from 1.5 to 6 had slightly intensified the last reduction peak, while Tmax experienced no significant alteration. It can be explained that the existence of lanthanum reinforced the interaction of NiO inside the solid matrix leading to more participation in solid solution formation and higher reduction temperature [49,50]. CO2-Temperature programmed desorption analysis (CO2-TPD) The basicity characteristic of the prepared samples including strength and quantity of basic sites was assessed via TPD analysis using CO2 as a probe molecule. The strength and number of basic centers are reflected by the CO2 desorption temperature and corresponding peak area, respectively. Fig. 4 represents the CO2-TPD curves of the catalysts with various La loadings. All the CO2-TPD spectra were deconvoluted into three main peaks via Gaussian type function and the quantitative results are reported in Table 2 . Depending on the CO2 desorption temperature, the strength of basic sites is categorized into four types: weak basic sites (T< 200 °C), moderate (200 °C-400 °C), strong (400 °C-600 °C) and very strong basic sites (T>600 °C). As can be observed, all the prepared samples showed a similar desorption pattern including three main desorption peaks at moderate (200-250 °C), strong (420-480 °C), and very strong (T>900 °C) regions [44]. Upon the addition of 1.5 wt. % La2O3, the number of basic sites in the strong and very-strong regions were increased. Meanwhile, temperature peaks of the moderate and strong regions were shifted toward lower values. The strength of moderate and strong basic sites declined whereas the number of strong and very strong basic sites increased. Further increase in the amount of La2O3 up to 4.5 wt. %, significantly enhanced the number and strength of basic sites. Eventfully for 6 wt. % La2O3 loading, largest extent of the basic sites was obtained, although the basic strength was lowered compared to 3 and 4.5 wt. % La2O3 loadings. In other words, for the 6 wt.% La2O3 loading the peak temperatures shifted to lower values compared with those of the 3 and 4.5 wt.% loadings. As a result, the incorporation of lanthanum caused a clear increase in the concentration of basic sites such a way that the highest CO2 uptake was obtained by the catalyst containing 6 wt. % La2O3. Upon the incorporation of lanthanum, the total number of strong and very strong-strength basic sites gradually increased leading to a larger amount of total basic sites in the promoted catalysts. According to the literature, CO2 would rather be adsorbed by La2O3 to form La2O2CO3 which is further anticipated to improve the catalyst resistance toward coke formation [51]. CO-Chemisorption analysis The influence of the La addition on the metal dispersion, surface area, and particle size was investigated through CO-chemisorption and the results are reported in Table 3 . As La2O3 content enhanced from 0 to 1.5 wt. %, Ni dispersion, and surface area decreased which might be due to the coverage of active sites by insufficient lanthanum species. As the La2O3 content increased from 1.5 to 3 wt. % a noticeable improvement in Ni dispersion and surface area was observed. The highest nickel dispersion of 15.8% as well as the corresponding surface area of 105.6 m2gmetal -1 were provided by 3 wt. % La2O3 loading. Moreover, the Ni particle size lowered from 15 nm to 6.4 nm for un-promoted and 3 wt. % La2O3 loading, respectively. The enhancement of Ni dispersion due to the existence of La promoter could be correlated with two main factors as followed: (i) highly dispersed La species and (ii) improved interaction between metal and supprt. As reported by authors [20,44], the well-dispersed La species on the catalyst surface, can play a “spacer” role between Ni crystallites and thereby prevent agglomeration and formation of larger particles during the reduction step. Moreover, as confirmed by TPR analysis, the incorporation of La improved the metal-support interaction which hindered the crystal growth and sintering of Ni particles. Nevertheless, a further increase in the La loading reduced the Ni dispersion, surface area, and particle size. It can be suggested that the excessive La addition covered the active metal surface leading to a decline in the number of effective Ni sites[52]. Catalytic performance evaluation The catalytic performance of the synthesized catalysts containing various amounts of La2O3 was studied during PSR in terms of propane conversion, yield of hydrogen production, product selectivities, and stability. The propane conversion and yield of hydrogen as a function of reaction temperature are displayed in Fig. 5 a and b. As one may observe, increasing the reaction temperature enhanced the propane conversion and hydrogen yield over all the prepared catalysts owning to the endothermic nature of the reforming reaction. Generally, the incorporation of La caused a slight decrease in propane conversion except for 3 wt. % loading which exposed the higher activity than the non-promoted catalyst. It can be perceived from Fig. 5 that 1.5 wt. % loading of La2O3 negatively affected the propane conversion and hydrogen yield under all the temperatures. Further increase in promoter loading up to 3 wt.%, slightly improved propane conversion and yield of hydrogen which is more discernible at higher reaction temperatures. The highest propane conversion and hydrogen yield of about 96% and 75% were obtained in the presence of this sample at 800 °C, respectively. It is apparent that propane conversion and H2 yield underwent a decrease as a result of more increase in the lanthanum oxide up to 6 wt. %. It is worthy to note that, hydrocarbon cracking reactions are more promoted by the catalysts including a larger number of acidic sites. It was reported that acidic sites decreased the electron density of metallic Ni species which is followed by accelerating hydrocarbons decomposition. As investigated by several authors, the addition of rare earth metals such as La can weaken the catalyst acidity which is not favorable for dissociation of adsorbed CHx species. Turning to 1.5 wt. % La2O3 loading, its lower activity comparing to La-free sample was induced by both less metallic surface area and acidic sites. Although further increase in La2O3 loading to 3 wt. % resulted in more decrease in acidic sites, the superior metal dispersion and corresponding surface area are more dominant which in turn to the perfect activity. As for higher loading of La2O3, the coverage of active sites by La atoms as well as considerable enhancement in surface basicity caused a gradual decline in the catalyst activity, which is more evident for 6 wt. % La2O3 loading. Fig. 6 describes the C- containing product selectivities as a function of reaction temperature. Propane steam reforming consists of a complex reaction network resulting in various desired and undesired C-containing products including CO, CO2, CH4 with relatively small amounts of C2H2,C2H4, C2H6, and C3H6. As can be seen from Fig. 6a, the CO selectivity steadily increased by raising the reaction temperature from 550 to 800 °C. This can be attributed to the more progress in hydrocarbons steam reforming as well as reverse water gas shift (WGS) reaction. As well known, high temperature does not favor the exothermic WGS reaction. More precisely, promoted catalysts provided higher CO selectivity comparing to un-promoted one. The lowest CO selectivity was achieved over the non-promoted catalyst while 3 wt. % La2O3 loading exhibited the highest selectivity over the whole range of operating temperatures. The above observation may support three surprising conclusions: (1) CO2 was adsorbed on the La2O3 basic sites to from La2O2CO3 which is converted to La2O3 and CO via Eq.4, (2) reverse WGS reaction was more promoted over the La-modified catalysts and the most over 3 wt. % loading, and (3) more progress toward other hydrogen production rousts such as hydrocarbon cracking comparing to steam reforming might have taken place over non-promoted catalyst. These results were further confirmed by the highest H2/CO and amount of carbon deposition over the La-free catalyst. CH4 as a competitive product of H2 is the main undesired by-product in steam reforming of propane which is produced more probably via CO and CO2 methanation. More deeply, during propane steam reforming methane can be produced via four plausible routes as followed: (i) carbon gasification by H2 (Eq.9),(ii) methanation (Eq.10a-b), (iii) propane hydrogenolysis (Eq.11), and (iv) propane cracking (Eq.12–13)[53,54]. (9) C + 2 H 2 ↔ C H 4 (10-a) C O + 3 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + H 2 O (10-b) C O 2 + 4 H 2 ↔ C H 4 + 2 H 2 O (11) C 3 H 8 + H 2 ↔ C 2 H 6 + C H 4 (12) C 3 H 8 ↔ C 2 H 4 + C H 4 (13) C 3 H 8 ↔ C 3 H 6 + H 2 In view of the fact that the rateIn view of the fact that the rate of carbon gasification decreases according to the following order: O2>H2O> H2, the first route seems implausible for methane production during the reaction condition [55]. Both CO/CO2 methanation and propane hydrogenolysis are exothermic reactions and consequently can be supposed as probable paths for methane production especially at low temperatures. However, the trace amount of C2H6 in the product stream (selectivity <2.5%-Fig. 6-d) weakens the occurrence of the third route. Concerning Eq. 12, it is an endothermic reaction that is thermodynamically feasible at a temperature higher than 300 °C[56]. The remarkable amount of C2H4 in product stream leads to consider the last reaction as a favorable route for CH4 production, particularly at high reaction temperatures. Turning to Fig. 6-b, over all the prepared catalysts, CH4 selectivity increased as the reaction temperature enhanced which is opposed to that reported by some literature and simulation results [3,56–58]. It can be explained that under the selected reaction condition (GHSV = 100,000 ml.grcat -1 h-1 and S/C = 1) the propane cracking route (Eq.12) was encouraged more than that observed under higher S/C ratio. The least methane selectivity was achieved upon 6 wt. % La2O3 loading which was balanced by higher CO2 selectivity. As can be seen from Fig. 6-c, the increase in the reaction temperature lowered the CO2 selectivity which can be ascribed to the progress in reverse WGS and Boudouard reaction. The highest CO2 selectivity observed over 6 wt. % La2O3 may be due to the more progress in WGS reaction and reverse Eq. (10-b) Fig. 6-d,e, and f show the selectivity of C2H6, C3H6 and C2H4, respectively. It is worthy to note that, these by-products resulted from propane cracking routes namely Eq.11,12, and 13. Increasing the reaction temperature gave rise to the corresponding selectivities as a result of the endothermic nature of the cracking reactions. The catalyst with 3 wt. % La2O3 loading provided the lowest C2H6, C3H6, and C2H4 which was accompanied by higher CO selectivity. It is reiterated that, although the highest C2H4 selectivity was detected over 6 wt. % La2O3, the more progress in reverse methanation reaction (Eq.10-b) led to lower CH selectivity compared to the other samples. The H2 to CO ratio in propane steam reforming over the prepared catalysts is shown as a function of reaction temperature, Fig. 7 . As can be seen, La incorporation provided lower H2/CO in downstream. As mentioned above, it could be assigned to the more progress in reverse WGS and carbon gasification through Eq.4 over the promoted catalysts. Upon the increase in La2O3 loading from 1.5 to 6 wt.%, the H2/CO was slightly increased due to the decrease in CO selectivity. Due to the fact that desirable H2/CO depends on the final product, the La-containing catalyst seems to be not appropriate for hydrogen-rich syngas production comparing to the La-free catalyst. Fig. 8 shows the propane conversion and yield of hydrogen during 20 h time on stream. As can be seen, over all the prepared catalysts the propane conversion and yield of hydrogen remained almost constant during 900 min period of reaction. As well known, Ni-based catalysts undergo severe deactivation especially at high reaction temperature because of coke deposition and sintering. In this study, the stable performance of the prepared catalysts can be associated with strong metal-support interaction along with well-dispersed Ni species and enhanced surface basicity. The strong interaction between metal and support prevented growth of Ni cluster and thereby resulting in more resistant catalysts against sintering. Besides, well-dispersed Ni species along with appropriate basic sites decreased the amount of coke deposition on the catalyst surface. It should be noted although the positive influence of the La promoter upon suppressing Ni particles sintering has been proven by many types of research, herein, there is no evidence to support this fact. Temperature programmed oxidation (TPO) analysis The TPO patterns of the spent catalysts after 20 h time on stream at 650 °C are displayed in Fig. 9 . All the prepared samples exposed the similar TPO profile including a downward peak between 300 and 400 °C which is followed by a single oxidation peak at high temperature region indicating the formation of only one type of carbonaceous species on the catalyst surface. According to the literature, the downward peak could be related to the re-oxidation of metallic Ni species which still remain in the catalyst [59]. Obviously, in comparison with non-promoted catalyst, the La-containing samples exhibited more intense negative peak. As mentioned before, the incorporation of lanthanum greatly enhanced Ni dispersion and decreased the size of Ni species. These smaller metal particles strongly interacted with the support are hardly oxidized [60]. The second distinct peak occurred around 700 °C which is assigned to the oxidation of filamentous/whisker type carbon. It should be noted that, this type of carbon is formed due to the diffusion of C-atoms upon the Ni crytals and growing at the top of it [61]. Although the whisker carbon ad no negative effect on the catalyst activity, it would indeed lead to the catalyst destruction and reactor blockage after a long time operation [62]. The results reveal that La-promoted catalysts exhibited a lower amount of carbon deposition comparing to un-promoted one. Based on the literature to manage coke disposition two determining factors including the size of Ni crystalline and basic characteristic of the catalyst should be considered. As confirmed by CO-chemisorption analysis, the addition of La2O3 significantly improved the metal dispersion and decreased the size of Ni particles. Due to this fact that the coke formation cannot be developed over the Ni crystalline smaller than the critical size[63–65], smaller Ni species decreased the chance of coke formation. Moreover, the concentration of basic sites increased by La addition which favored CO2 adsorption to form La2O2CO3. The deposited carbon can be eliminated “in-situ” through the reaction of activating carbon with the surface carbonate [49]. As can be seen from Fig. 9, the amount of deposited carbon decreased upon the increase in La2O3 from 1.5 to 3 wt. % whereas further enhancement in prompter loading up to 6 wt. % represented a slight increase in the amount of deposited carbon. It emphasized that the amount of deposited carbon is associated with the size of Ni particles; smaller Ni species lowered the amount of deposited coke and larger Ni particles facilitated carbon formation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) The SEM micrographs of the spent catalysts after 900 min of reaction duration are displayed in Figs. 10 . One noticed that the whisker type carbon was formed over all spent catalysts in the form of hollow cylindrical filaments. Obviously, increasing the lanthanum loading up to 3 wt. % decreased the amount of deposited carbon. Further addition of La2O3 loading caused a gradual increase in the amount of deposited carbon. These results are consistent with those concluded from the TPO analysis presented earlier in this paper. Conclusion NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts were modified with different amounts of La2O3 and employed in the steam reforming of propane. The obtained results revealed that the La-containing samples exposed a lower BET surface area owning to partial blockage of small pores by the La particles. Moreover, the La2O3 species acted as a “spacer” preventing the Ni particles’ agglomeration. This led to higher Ni dispersion and available metallic surface area in promoted catalysts compared with those of the un-promoted one. However, the excessive amount of La covering the active sites negatively affected the metal dispersion and accessible surface area. The evaluation of the catalytic performance revealed that the appropriate La2O3 loading of 3 wt. % led to the highest activity which could be induced by strong metal-support interaction, excellent nickel dispersion, and sufficient Ni surface area available for chemisorption and reaction. Further La loading beyond this value caused a decrease in the catalyst activity because of a reduction in the acidic sites which were responsible for the CHx cracking. Moreover, the promoted catalysts resulted in a lower amount of coke deposition compared to that of the un-promoted one. This occurred in such a way that, the lowest amount of carbon deposition was observed upon the catalyst containing 3 wt. % La2O3. This inhibition of coke deposition was attributed to the enhanced basic property and CO2 adsorption to form La2O2CO3 phase as well as a better dispersion of active metals upon the promoted catalysts. This study revealed that the appropriate amount of La2O3 loading provided superior catalytic performance and coke resistance as a consequence of highly dispersed Ni species and sufficient acid-basic sites leading to a promising candidate for the catalytic steam reforming of propane. coredata.dc:description: In this study, 15 wt. % NiO-MgO-SiO2 catalysts modified by La2O3 promoter were prepared through a co-precipitation route and employed for syngas production via propane steam reforming. Various techniques including X-Ray diffraction, BET, TPR, CO2-TPD, CO-chemisorption, TPO, and Scanning electron microscopy were utilized to characterize the final samples. The results indicated that the incorporation of La2O3 enhanced the metal-support interaction providing less reducible Ni species. In comparison with the La-free catalyst, the promoted ones possessed higher metal dispersion and smaller Ni particles. Nonetheless, excessive amounts of La covering the active sites negatively decreased the Ni dispersion and corresponding surface area. In addition, upon the introduction of La2O3 the strength and amount of strong basic sites enhanced owing to the preferential adsorption of CO2 on La2O3. The evaluation of the catalytic performance disclosed that despite the improved metal dispersion, the promoted catalysts possessed lower propane conversion and hydrogen yield than the un-promoted one. It might be attributed to the decrease in the acidic sites which contributed to CHx decomposition. Nevertheless, the highest activity was achieved with 3 wt. % La2O3 loading which was induced by highly dispersed metallic Ni and more accessible active sites for adsorption and dissociation. It was also confirmed that, the existence of La2O3 improved the resistance against coke formation owning to the formation of well-dispersed Ni species and acceleration of gasification reaction through the La2O2CO3.
coredata.dc:title: The Influence of Lanthanide on NiO-MgO-SiO2 Catalysts for Syngas Production via Propane Steam Reforming
